title: Protocol of living cell separation using the microfluidic dielectrophoresis integrated chip
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Setting up instrument
Timing: 5 min
Turn on the computer power switch.
Turn on the cell-sorting device power switch.
Double-click the cell-sorting device software icon to open the operation screen.
Sample preparation
Timing: 30 min
In this section, dead and alive Jurkat cells are prepared at 50:50.
Equilibrate buffer to room temperature before use to avoid condensation.
Equilibrate sample media to room temperature to avoid condensation.
Equilibrate alive Jurkat cell culture and dead Jurkat cell culture to room temperature.
Note: It is recommended that samples be at room temperature, consistent with the buffer temperature. A cold buffer and sample can cause condensation and a slow flow rate. It is also necessary to avoid over-equilibration time to maintain the cell's viability.
Measure cell density and survival rate with a cell counter.
Dilute both cell cultures to approximately 1 × 106 cells/mL with sample media.
Mix live and dead cell cultures at approximately 50:50 to prepare 50% viability at 1 × 106 cells/mL (total of alive and dead cells).
Note: The upper limit of cell concentration is recommended at 1 × 106 cells/mL. The cell concentration above the limit can cause inaccuracy in cell counting with the video analysis. Conversely, there is no lower cell concentration limit.
Chip decompression
Timing: 5 min
In this section, a chip is decompressed immediately before use so that the microchannel of the chip can be adequately filled with fluid.
Remove aluminum bad and take out sterile pouch containing a chip.
Note: The chip is double wrapped, inner with a sterile pouch and outer with an aluminum cover. Remove and discard only the aluminum cover.
Place the chip covered with the sterile pouch into a vacuum desiccator.
Close the vacuum desiccator lid.

Start the vacuum and slowly degas using an arbitrary generator, and leave it for exactly 5 min.
Critical: Over-decompression or insufficient decompression will cause inadequate cell sorting.
Turn off the vacuum and slowly release the vacuum state. Wait until the vacuum gauge reaches 0 MPa.
Open the vacuum desiccator, and remove the chip covered with sterile pouch.
Critical: After removing the chip from vacuum desiccator, immediately proceed to the next step to set the chip in the cell-sorting device.
Chip installation
Timing: 2 min
This section introduces chip installation to the cell-sorting device (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1811-Fig1.jpg
Figure 1. Schematic design of the microfluidic dielectrophoresis chip
The figure is from Oshiro et al. (2022)[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2].
Open the sterile pouch and take out the decompressed chip.
Critical: After removing chip from sterile pouch, do not touch the inlet and outlet ports of the chip to avoid contamination.
Place the chip on the glass stage of cell-sorting device while holding Chip Lock Lever by hand (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]). Ensure that the Inlet 1 and Inlet 2 of the chip are on the left corner.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1811-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Chip on the glass stage of the cell-sorting device
Push the chip to back unit it latches.
Note: Ensure that Chip Device Lever is up before pushing the chip to back, or the probe unit may be damaged.
Lock Chip Device Lever to set the chip position.
Buffer filling
Timing: 5 min
This section introduces buffer filling in the cell-sorting device and chip.
Note: Buffer must be equilibrated at room temperature before use to avoid condensation.
Take out the longer tube (buffer tube) from a tube set and connect it to a syringe.

Note: There are two tubes in the kit, one for buffer and the other for sample. Be sure to use the longer one for buffer solution.
Manually draw buffer until it reaches 1/3 to 1/2 of the syringe volume.
Turn the syringe tip upward and tap the syringe to move air from the tube. Push the piston of the syringe to let all air out.
Critical: If air bubbles remain in the system, it will affect the constant flow rate.
Draw up the buffer to fill the syringe.
Install the syringe to Syringe Pump 1 of the cell-sorting device (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1811-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Syringe Pump 1 and 2 of cell-sorting device
Syringe Pump 1 is for buffer, and syringe Pump 2 is for sample.
Insert the other end of the buffer tube into Inlet port 1 attached to the chip (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1811-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. Buffer tube and chip connection
Insert the end of the buffer tube into Inlet port 1 and the sample tube into Inlet port 2.
Critical: Make sure to insert the buffer tube all the way to Inlet port 1, or the tube can pop off during cell sorting operation.
Click Push Plate Fast Descending Button of buffer on the software (6 in Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1811-Fig5.jpg
Figure 5. Syringe control panel and Wave control panel
In the syringe control panel (top), the left side controls buffer and the right side controls sample. Each button function is listed in Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1].
table:files/protocols_protocol_1811_1.csv
Syringe Control panel buttons # 1–10 refer to Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]. Waveform Control Panel buttons # 11–16 refer to Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]. Analysis Panel buttons # 17–23 refer to Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7].
Note: Press once, and the push plate descends and automatically stops when it touches the syringe plunger.

Press and hold Push Plate Descending Button (5 in Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]) to descend the plunger until the buffer fills the chip and drips from Inlet port 2, Outlet port 1, Outlet port 2, and Outlet port 3.
Critical: Make sure there is no air left in the chip.
Keep feeding the buffer in the system for more than 10 min.
Critical: Successful cell sorting may not be achieved with a shorter conditioning time.
Sample filling
Timing: 5 min
This section introduces sample setting.
Note: Sample must be equilibrated at room temperature.
Take out the shorter tube (sample tube) from a tube set and connect it to a syringe.
Note: There are two tubes in the kit, one for buffer and the other for sample. Be sure to use the shorter one for sample.
Draw the sample into the syringe in the same procedure as the buffer.
Install the syringe to Syringe Pump 2 (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
Position the sample tube near Outlet port 3 (not shown).
Click the plunger Fast descending button of the sample on the software (6 in Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]).
Note: Press once, and the push plate descends and stops when it touches the syringe plunger.
Press and hold the fluid delivery button on the sample side until a drop comes out from the end of the sample tube (5 in Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]).
Ensure Inlet port 2 is filled with buffer. Then, insert the sample tube into Inlet port 2.
Critical: Ensure no air bubbles enter into Inlet port 2 (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]).
Microscope setting
Timing: 5 min
This section introduces the setting of a microscope attached to the cell-sorting device.
Adjust screen brightness with Brightness Adjustment Dial of the cell-sorting device located below the syringe pump compartment (not shown).

Use Left/Right Adjustment Knob and Front/Rear Adjustment Knob to capture the screen (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1811-Fig6.jpg
Figure 6. Microscope setting
Focus images with Focus Adjustment Knob (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]).
Cell sorting by manual mode
Timing: 40 min
This section describes cell sorting operation using manual mode.
Optional: Automatic mode is also available in the software.
On the syringe control panel, enter flow rate from the drop-down list (9 in Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]).
Note: Based on the method optimization test, 30 μL/min for 33 min run time is used to separate alive Jurkat cells from dead cells.
Set output method for CH1 and CH2 on the waveform control panel (13 in Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]).
Note: Select continuous if target cells are to be collected continuously, which is used for sample enrichment purposes. Otherwise, select ON/OFF.
If continuous is deselected, check ☑ and enter liquid feed time (8 in Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]).
Note: In this study, 33 min is entered.
Set frequency with ▲ ▼ button (14 in Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]).
Note: In this study, 3,000 kHz is entered. This parameter must be determined by a method optimization experiment for each target cell.
Set voltage with ▲ ▼ button (15 in Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]).
Note: In this study, 14 Vpp is entered. This parameter must be determined by a method optimization experiment for each target cell.
Press Liquid Transfer Start/Stop button on the syringe control panel for buffer (10 in Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]).
Critical: Be sure to start feeding buffer first before sample. To stabilize the flow, a buffer feeding time of 30 s for 1 mL syringe and 5 min for 10 mL syringe is required.
Remove buffer accumulated in Outlet port 1, Outlet port 2, and Outlet port 3 using sterile pipettes. Make sure all ports are empty.

Press Liquid Transfer Start/Stop button on the syringe control panel for sample (10 in Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]).
Note: In this study, 1 mL sample (alive cells: dead cells = 50:50 at total 1 × 106 cells/mL, n=3) is passed through the system.
Optional: Buffer exchange can be recorded by pressing [Start] on the monitoring screen (not shown).
Focus microscope with Focus Adjustment Knob (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]).
Press [Start] on the waveform control panel for dielectric separation (16 in Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]).
Optional: If necessary, click [Start] on the recording button (not shown). The video is saved in the folder (Windows (C :)> CROSSORTER_WORK> Video) that is automatically created with recording date and time.
Using sterile pipettes, transfer separated cells from Outlet port 1 and Outlet port 2 in sterile containers.
Note: Collect solution in Outlet port 1 first.
After the target sample volume has passed through the cell-sorting device, press [Stop] on the camera setting panel, waveform control panel, syringe control panel, and solution monitor.
Measure cell density and survival rate of sample collected from Outlet port 1 and Outlet port 2 with a cell counter.
Measure collected cells in Outlet port 1 and Outlet port 2 using the analysis function of the software (see below section, quantitative analysis[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec2.9]).
Quantitative analysis
Timing: 5 min
This section introduces how to analyze cell separation efficiency using a video recording function. This function provides the number of cells captured by Outlet 1 and Outlet 2 in 10 s increments.
Press Analysis Tab to display the analysis screen (17 in Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1811-Fig7.jpg
Figure 7. Analysis screen
Each button function is listed in Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1].
Click File Selection button to select a video file to be analyzed (18 in Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]).
Set a branch point (19 in Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]).

Set the horizontal line aligned with the middle of flow path branch.
Set the vertical line to the measurement position.
Note: Start with 500 px and move as needed.
Set analysis area (20 in Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]).
Optional: Analysis can be performed without setting analysis area. Unclick Analysis Area check box if not needed.
Click Analysis Start button (21 in Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]).
Check the degree of cell recognition. Adjust each setting if necessary.
Ensure the setting is correct, then press Analysis Stop button (21 in Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]).
Note: Once [Analysis start] button is clicked, the same icon changes to [Analysis stop] button.
Note: The count can be reset with Count Reset button (22 in Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]).
Start cell counting.
Set a play speed of the video and specify the start and stop positions of the video.
Click Analysis Start button again to execute video analysis of the selected section (21 in Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]).
Press Count CSV Output button on the analysis screen (23 in Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]). Save the file (Table S1[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1811-Mmc1.xlsx]).
Closing and cleaning
Timing: 5 min
This section describes cleaning and turning off the system.
Remove the syringes from Syringe Pump 1 and Syringe Pump 2 (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
Remove the tubes from Inlet port 1 and Inlet port 2.
Raise Chip Mounting Lever (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).
While pushing Chip Lock Lever by hand, move the chip forward.
Note: Make sure Chip Mounting Lever is up, or the probe may be damaged.
Remove the chip from the glass stage (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).
Click “x” at the top right corner of the operation screen.
Turn off the computer.
Turn off the power switch on the right side of the cell-sorting device.
Follow-up culture experiment
Timing: 4 days

This section describes an experiment to confirm that the alive cells are selectively collected through the cell-sorting system.
Measure the cell density and survival rate of sample collected from Outlet port 1 and Outlet port 2 with a cell counter.
Note: The collected cells are in the buffer at this point.
Dilute the cells with RPMI 1640 medium supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum, 100 U/mL penicillin, and 100 mg/mL streptomycin to approximately 5 × 104 cells/mL. Dispense 1 mL of the culture into 12-wells plates and incubate at 37°C in a 5% CO2 atmosphere.
Note: Two controls containing alive cells only are prepared, the Jukart culture with and without passing the cell-sorting system.
Every 24 h up to 4 days, record cell counts of the culture prepared from Outlet 1, Outlet 2, and controls.
